text: A man there hath been in the land of Uz -- Job his name -- and that man hath been perfect and upright -- both fearing God, and turning aside from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there are borne to him seven sons and three daughters,
speaker: Narrator

text: and his substance is seven thousand sheep, and three thousand camels, and five hundred pairs of oxen, and five hundred she-asses, and a service very abundant; and that man is greater than any of the sons of the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: And his sons have gone and made a banquet -- the house of each [in] his day -- and have sent and called to their three sisters to eat and to drink with them;
speaker: Narrator

text: and it cometh to pass, when they have gone round the days of the banquet, that Job doth send and sanctify them, and hath risen early in the morning, and caused to ascend burnt-offerings -- the number of them all -- for Job said, `Perhaps my sons have sinned, yet blessed God in their heart.' Thus doth Job all the days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the day is, that sons of God come in to station themselves by Jehovah, and there doth come also the Adversary in their midst.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehovah saith unto the Adversary, `Whence comest thou?' And the Adversary answereth Jehovah and saith, `From going to and fro in the land, and from walking up and down on it.'
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehovah saith unto the Adversary, `Hast thou set thy heart against My servant Job because there is none like him in the land, a man perfect and upright, fearing God, and turning aside from evil?'
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Adversary answereth Jehovah and saith, `For nought is Job fearing God?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast not Thou made a hedge for him, and for his house, and for all that he hath -- round about?
speaker: Narrator

text: The work of his hands Thou hast blessed, and his substance hath spread in the land, and yet, put forth, I pray Thee, Thy hand, and strike against anything that he hath -- if not: to Thy face he doth bless Thee!'
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehovah saith unto the Adversary, `Lo, all that he hath [is] in thy hand, only unto him put not forth thy hand.' And the Adversary goeth out from the presence of Jehovah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the day is, that his sons and his daughters are eating, and drinking wine, in the house of their brother, the first-born.
speaker: Narrator

text: And a messenger hath come in unto Job and saith, `The oxen have been plowing, and the she-asses feeding by their sides,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Sheba doth fall, and take them, and the young men they have smitten by the mouth of the sword, and I am escaped -- only I alone -- to declare [it] to thee.'
speaker: Narrator

text: While this [one] is speaking another also hath come and saith, `Fire of God hath fallen from the heavens, and burneth among the flock, and among the young men, and consumeth them, and I am escaped -- only I alone -- to declare [it] to thee.'
speaker: Narrator

text: While this [one] is speaking another also hath come and saith, `Chaldeans made three heads, and rush on the camels, and take them, and the young men they have smitten by the mouth of the sword, and I am escaped -- only I alone -- to declare [it] to thee.'
speaker: Narrator

text: While this [one] is speaking another also hath come and saith, `Thy sons and thy daughters are eating, and drinking wine, in the house of their brother, the first-born.
speaker: Narrator

text: And lo, a great wind hath come from over the wilderness, and striketh against the four corners of the house, and it falleth on the young men, and they are dead, and I am escaped -- only I alone -- to declare [it] to thee.'
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job riseth, and rendeth his robe, and shaveth his head, and falleth to the earth, and doth obeisance,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he saith, `Naked came I forth from the womb of my mother, and naked I turn back thither: Jehovah hath given and Jehovah hath taken: let the name of Jehovah be blessed.'
speaker: Narrator

text: In all this Job hath not sinned, nor given folly to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the day is, that sons of God come in to station themselves by Jehovah, and there doth come also the Adversary in their midst to station himself by Jehovah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehovah saith unto the Adversary, `Whence camest thou?' And the Adversary answereth Jehovah and saith, `From going to and fro in the land, and from walking up and down in it.'
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehovah saith unto the Adversary, `Hast thou set thy heart unto My servant Job because there is none like him in the land, a man perfect and upright, fearing God and turning aside from evil? and still he is keeping hold on his integrity, and thou dost move Me against him to swallow him up for nought!'
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Adversary answereth Jehovah and saith, `A skin for a skin, and all that a man hath he doth give for his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet, put forth, I pray Thee, Thy hand, and strike unto his bone and unto his flesh -- if not: unto Thy face he doth bless Thee!'
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehovah saith unto the Adversary, `Lo, he [is] in thy hand; only his life take care of.'
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Adversary goeth forth from the presence of Jehovah, and smiteth Job with a sore ulcer from the sole of his foot unto his crown.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he taketh to him a potsherd to scrape himself with it, and he is sitting in the midst of the ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: And his wife saith to him, `Still thou art keeping hold on thine integrity: bless God and die.'
speaker: Narrator

text: And he saith unto her, `As one of the foolish women speaketh, thou speakest; yea, the good we receive from God, and the evil we do not receive.' In all this Job hath not sinned with his lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: And three of the friends of Job hear of all this evil that hath come upon him, and they come in each from his place -- Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite -- and they are met together to come in to bemoan him, and to comfort him;
speaker: Narrator

text: and they lift up their eyes from afar and have not discerned him, and they lift up their voice and weep, and rend each his robe, and sprinkle dust on their heads -- heavenward.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they sit with him on the earth seven days and seven nights, and there is none speaking unto him a word when they have seen that the pain hath been very great.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this hath Job opened his mouth, and revileth his day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the day perish in which I am born, And the night that hath said: `A man-child hath been conceived.'
speaker: Narrator

text: That day -- let it be darkness, Let not God require it from above, Nor let light shine upon it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let darkness and death-shade redeem it, Let a cloud tabernacle upon it, Let them terrify it as the most bitter of days.
speaker: Narrator

text: That night -- let thick darkness take it, Let it not be united to days of the year, Into the number of months let it not come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo! that night -- let it be gloomy, Let no singing come into it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the cursers of day mark it, Who are ready to wake up Leviathan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the stars of its twilight be dark, Let it wait for light, and there is none, And let it not look on the eyelids of the dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because it hath not shut the doors Of the womb that was mine! And hide misery from mine eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why from the womb do I not die? From the belly I have come forth and gasp!
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore have knees been before me? And what [are] breasts, that I suck?
speaker: Narrator

text: For now, I have lain down, and am quiet, I have slept -- then there is rest to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: With kings and counsellors of earth, These building wastes for themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or with princes -- they have gold, They are filling their houses [with] silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Or as a hidden abortion I am not, As infants -- they have not seen light.)
speaker: Narrator

text: There the wicked have ceased troubling, And there rest do the wearied in power.
speaker: Narrator

text: Together prisoners have been at ease, They have not heard the voice of an exactor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Small and great [are] there the same. And a servant [is] free from his lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why giveth He to the miserable light, and life to the bitter soul?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who are waiting for death, and it is not, And they seek it above hid treasures.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who are glad -- unto joy, They rejoice when they find a grave.
speaker: Narrator

text: To a man whose way hath been hidden, And whom God doth shut up?
speaker: Narrator

text: For before my food, my sighing cometh, And poured out as waters [are] my roarings.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a fear I feared and it meeteth me, And what I was afraid of doth come to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was not safe -- nor was I quiet -- Nor was I at rest -- and trouble cometh!
speaker: Narrator

text: And Eliphaz the Temanite answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Hath one tried a word with thee? -- Thou art weary! And to keep in words who is able?
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, thou hast instructed many, And feeble hands thou makest strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: The stumbling one do thy words raise up, And bowing knees thou dost strengthen.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, it cometh in unto thee, And thou art weary; It striketh unto thee, and thou art troubled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not thy reverence thy confidence? Thy hope -- the perfection of thy ways?
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember, I pray thee, Who, being innocent, hath perished? And where have the upright been cut off?
speaker: Narrator

text: As I have seen -- ploughers of iniquity, And sowers of misery, reap it!
speaker: Narrator

text: From the breath of God they perish, And from the spirit of His anger consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The roaring of a lion, And the voice of a fierce lion, And teeth of young lions have been broken.
speaker: Narrator

text: An old lion is perishing without prey, And the whelps of the lioness do separate.
speaker: Narrator

text: And unto me a thing is secretly brought, And receive doth mine ear a little of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: In thoughts from visions of the night, In the falling of deep sleep on men,
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear hath met me, and trembling, And the multitude of my bones caused to fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: And a spirit before my face doth pass, Stand up doth the hair of my flesh;
speaker: Narrator

text: It standeth, and I discern not its aspect, A similitude [is] over-against mine eyes, Silence! and a voice I hear:
speaker: Narrator

text: `Is mortal man than God more righteous? Than his Maker is a man cleaner?
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, in His servants He putteth no credence, Nor in His messengers setteth praise.'
speaker: Narrator

text: Also -- the inhabitants of houses of clay, (Whose foundation [is] in the dust, They bruise them before a moth.)
speaker: Narrator

text: From morning to evening are beaten down, Without any regarding, for ever they perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hath not their excellency been removed with them? They die, and not in wisdom!
speaker: Narrator

text: Pray, call, is there any to answer thee? And unto which of the holy ones dost thou turn?
speaker: Narrator

text: For provocation slayeth the perverse, And envy putteth to death the simple,
speaker: Narrator

text: I -- I have seen the perverse taking root, And I mark his habitation straightway,
speaker: Narrator

text: Far are his sons from safety, And they are bruised in the gate, And there is no deliverer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whose harvest the hungry doth eat, And even from the thorns taketh it, And the designing swallowed their wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For sorrow cometh not forth from the dust, Nor from the ground springeth up misery.
speaker: Narrator

text: For man to misery is born, And the sparks go high to fly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet I -- I inquire for God, And for God I give my word,
speaker: Narrator

text: Doing great things, and there is no searching. Wonderful, till there is no numbering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is giving rain on the face of the land, And is sending waters on the out-places.
speaker: Narrator

text: To set the low on a high place, And the mourners have been high [in] safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: Making void thoughts of the subtile, And their hands do not execute wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Capturing the wise in their subtilty, And the counsel of wrestling ones was hastened,
speaker: Narrator

text: By day they meet darkness, And as night -- they grope at noon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He saveth the wasted from their mouth, And from a strong hand the needy,
speaker: Narrator

text: And there is hope to the poor, And perverseness hath shut her mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, the happiness of mortal man, God doth reprove him: And the chastisement of the Mighty despise not,
speaker: Narrator

text: For He doth pain, and He bindeth up, He smiteth, and His hands heal.
speaker: Narrator

text: In six distresses He delivereth thee, And in seven evil striketh not on thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: In famine He hath redeemed thee from death, And in battle from the hands of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the tongue scourgeth thou art hid, And thou art not afraid of destruction, When it cometh.
speaker: Narrator

text: At destruction and at hunger thou mockest, And of the beast of the earth, Thou art not afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: (For with sons of the field [is] thy covenant, And the beast of the field Hath been at peace with thee.)
speaker: Narrator

text: And thou hast known that thy tent [is] peace, And inspected thy habitation, and errest not,
speaker: Narrator

text: And hast known that numerous [is] Thy seed, And thine offspring as the herb of the earth;
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou comest in full age unto the grave, As the going up of a stalk in its season.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, this -- we searched it out -- it [is] right, hearken; And thou, know for thyself!
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: O that my provocation were thoroughly weighed, And my calamity in balances They would lift up together!
speaker: Narrator

text: For now, than the sands of the sea it is heavier, Therefore my words have been rash.
speaker: Narrator

text: For arrows of the Mighty [are] with me, Whose poison is drinking up my spirit. Terrors of God array themselves [for] me!
speaker: Narrator

text: Brayeth a wild ass over tender grass? Loweth an ox over his provender?
speaker: Narrator

text: Eaten is an insipid thing without salt? Is there sense in the drivel of dreams?
speaker: Narrator

text: My soul is refusing to touch! They [are] as my sickening food.
speaker: Narrator

text: O that my request may come, That God may grant my hope!
speaker: Narrator

text: That God would please -- and bruise me, Loose His hand and cut me off!
speaker: Narrator

text: And yet it is my comfort, (And I exult in pain -- He doth not spare,) That I have not hidden The sayings of the Holy One.
speaker: Narrator

text: What [is] my power that I should hope? And what mine end That I should prolong my life?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is my strength the strength of stones? Is my flesh brazen?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not my help with me, And substance driven from me?
speaker: Narrator

text: To a despiser of his friends [is] shame, And the fear of the Mighty he forsaketh.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brethren have deceived as a brook, As a stream of brooks they pass away.
speaker: Narrator

text: That are black because of ice, By them doth snow hide itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the time they are warm they have been cut off, By its being hot they have been Extinguished from their place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn aside do the paths of their way, They ascend into emptiness, and are lost.
speaker: Narrator

text: Passengers of Tema looked expectingly, Travellers of Sheba hoped for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were ashamed that one hath trusted, They have come unto it and are confounded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely now ye have become the same! Ye see a downfall, and are afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it because I said, Give to me? And, By your power bribe for me?
speaker: Narrator

text: And, Deliver me from the hand of an adversary? And, From the hand of terrible ones ransom me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Shew me, and I -- I keep silent, And what I have erred, let me understand.
speaker: Narrator

text: How powerful have been upright sayings, And what doth reproof from you reprove?
speaker: Narrator

text: For reproof -- do you reckon words? And for wind -- sayings of the desperate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anger on the fatherless ye cause to fall, And are strange to your friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: And, now, please, look upon me, Even to your face do I lie?
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn back, I pray you, let it not be perverseness, Yea, turn back again -- my righteousness [is] in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is there in my tongue perverseness? Discerneth not my palate desirable things?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is there not a warfare to man on earth? And as the days of an hireling his days?
speaker: Narrator

text: As a servant desireth the shadow, And as a hireling expecteth his wage,
speaker: Narrator

text: So I have been caused to inherit months of vanity, And nights of misery they numbered to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I lay down then I said, `When do I rise!' And evening hath been measured, And I have been full of tossings till dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Clothed hath been my flesh [with] worms, And a clod of dust, My skin hath been shrivelled and is loathsome,
speaker: Narrator

text: My days swifter than a weaving machine, And they are consumed without hope.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember Thou that my life [is] a breath, Mine eye turneth not back to see good.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eye of my beholder beholdeth me not. Thine eyes [are] upon me -- and I am not.
speaker: Narrator

text: Consumed hath been a cloud, and it goeth, So he who is going down to Sheol cometh not up.
speaker: Narrator

text: He turneth not again to his house, Nor doth his place discern him again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also I -- I withhold not my mouth -- I speak in the distress of my spirit, I talk in the bitterness of my soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: A sea-[monster] am I, or a dragon, That thou settest over me a guard?
speaker: Narrator

text: When I said, `My bed doth comfort me,' He taketh away in my talking my couch.
speaker: Narrator

text: And thou hast affrighted me with dreams, And from visions thou terrifiest me,
speaker: Narrator

text: And my soul chooseth strangling, Death rather than my bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have wasted away -- not to the age do I live. Cease from me, for my days [are] vanity.
speaker: Narrator

text: What [is] man that Thou dost magnify him? And that Thou settest unto him Thy heart?
speaker: Narrator

text: And inspectest him in the mornings, In the evenings dost try him?
speaker: Narrator

text: How long dost Thou not look from me? Thou dost not desist till I swallow my spittle.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have sinned, what do I to Thee, O watcher of man? Why hast Thou set me for a mark to Thee, And I am for a burden to myself -- and what?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou dost not take away my transgression, And cause to pass away mine iniquity, Because now, for dust I lie down: And Thou hast sought me -- and I am not!
speaker: Narrator

text: And Bildad the Shuhite answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Till when dost thou speak these things? And a strong wind -- sayings of thy mouth?
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth God pervert judgment? And doth the Mighty One pervert justice?
speaker: Narrator

text: If thy sons have sinned before Him, And He doth send them away, By the hand of their transgression,
speaker: Narrator

text: If thou dost seek early unto God, And unto the Mighty makest supplication,
speaker: Narrator

text: If pure and upright thou [art], Surely now He waketh for thee, And hath completed The habitation of thy righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: And thy beginning hath been small, And thy latter end is very great.
speaker: Narrator

text: For, ask I pray thee of a former generation, And prepare to a search of their fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text: (For of yesterday we [are], and we know not, For a shadow [are] our days on earth.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Do they not shew thee -- speak to thee, And from their heart bring forth words?
speaker: Narrator

text: `Doth a rush wise without mire? A reed increase without water?
speaker: Narrator

text: While it [is] in its budding -- uncropt, Even before any herb it withereth.
speaker: Narrator

text: So [are] the paths of all forgetting God, And the hope of the profane doth perish,
speaker: Narrator

text: Whose confidence is loathsome, And the house of a spider his trust.
speaker: Narrator

text: He leaneth on his house -- and it standeth not: He taketh hold on it -- and it abideth not.
speaker: Narrator

text: Green he [is] before the sun, And over his garden his branch goeth out.
speaker: Narrator

text: By a heap his roots are wrapped, A house of stones he looketh for.
speaker: Narrator

text: If [one] doth destroy him from his place, Then it hath feigned concerning him, I have not seen thee!
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, this [is] the joy of his way, And from the dust others spring up.'
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, God doth not reject the perfect, Nor taketh hold on the hand of evil doers.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he filleth with laughter thy mouth, And thy lips with shouting,
speaker: Narrator

text: Those hating thee do put on shame, And the tent of the wicked is not!
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Truly I have known that [it is] so, And what -- is man righteous with God?
speaker: Narrator

text: If he delight to strive with Him -- He doth not answer him one of a thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wise in heart and strong in power -- Who hath hardened toward Him and is at peace?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is removing mountains, And they have not known, Who hath overturned them in His anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is shaking earth from its place, And its pillars move themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is speaking to the sun, and it riseth not, And the stars He sealeth up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stretching out the heavens by Himself, And treading on the heights of the sea,
speaker: Narrator

text: Making Osh, Kesil, and Kimah, And the inner chambers of the south.
speaker: Narrator

text: Doing great things till there is no searching, And wonderful, till there is no numbering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, He goeth over by me, and I see not, And He passeth on, and I attend not to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, He snatches away, who bringeth it back? Who saith unto Him, `What dost Thou?'
speaker: Narrator

text: God doth not turn back His anger, Under Him bowed have proud helpers.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much less do I -- I answer Him? Choose out my words with Him?
speaker: Narrator

text: Whom, though I were righteous, I answer not, For my judgment I make supplication.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though I had called and He answereth me, I do not believe that He giveth ear [to] my voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because with a tempest He bruiseth me, And hath multiplied my wounds for nought.
speaker: Narrator

text: He permitteth me not to refresh my spirit, But filleth me with bitter things.
speaker: Narrator

text: If of power, lo, the Strong One; And if of judgment -- who doth convene me?
speaker: Narrator

text: If I be righteous, Mine mouth doth declare me wicked, Perfect I am! -- it declareth me perverse.
speaker: Narrator

text: Perfect I am! -- I know not my soul, I despise my life.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is the same thing, therefore I said, `The perfect and the wicked He is consuming.'
speaker: Narrator

text: If a scourge doth put to death suddenly, At the trial of the innocent He laugheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Earth hath been given Into the hand of the wicked one. The face of its judges he covereth, If not -- where, who [is] he?
speaker: Narrator

text: My days have been swifter than a runner, They have fled, they have not seen good,
speaker: Narrator

text: They have passed on with ships of reed, As an eagle darteth on food.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though I say, `I forget my talking, I forsake my corner, and I brighten up!'
speaker: Narrator

text: I have been afraid of all my griefs, I have known that Thou dost not acquit me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I -- I am become wicked; why [is] this? [In] vain I labour.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I have washed myself with snow-water, And purified with soap my hands,
speaker: Narrator

text: Then in corruption Thou dost dip me, And my garments have abominated me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a man like myself -- I answer him, We come together into judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there were between us an umpire, He doth place his hand on us both.
speaker: Narrator

text: He doth turn aside from off me his rod, And His terror doth not make me afraid,
speaker: Narrator

text: I speak, and do not fear Him, But I am not right with myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: My soul hath been weary of my life, I leave off my talking to myself, I speak in the bitterness of my soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: I say unto God, `Do not condemn me, Let me know why Thou dost strive [with] me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it good for Thee that Thou dost oppress? That Thou despisest the labour of Thy hands, And on the counsel of the wicked hast shone?
speaker: Narrator

text: Eyes of flesh hast Thou? As man seeth -- seest Thou?
speaker: Narrator

text: As the days of man [are] Thy days? Thy years as the days of a man?
speaker: Narrator

text: That Thou inquirest for mine iniquity, And for my sin seekest?
speaker: Narrator

text: For Thou knowest that I am not wicked, And there is no deliverer from Thy hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy hands have taken pains about me, And they make me together round about, And Thou swallowest me up!
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember, I pray Thee, That as clay Thou hast made me, And unto dust Thou dost bring me back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost Thou not as milk pour me out? And as cheese curdle me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Skin and flesh Thou dost put on me, And with bones and sinews dost fence me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Life and kindness Thou hast done with me. And Thy inspection hath preserved my spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: And these Thou hast laid up in Thy heart, I have known that this [is] with Thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I sinned, then Thou hast observed me, And from mine iniquity dost not acquit me,
speaker: Narrator

text: If I have done wickedly -- wo to me, And righteously -- I lift not up my head, Full of shame -- then see my affliction,
speaker: Narrator

text: And it riseth -- as a lion Thou huntest me. And Thou turnest back -- Thou shewest Thyself wonderful in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou renewest Thy witnesses against me, And dost multiply Thine anger with me, Changes and warfare [are] with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And why from the womb Hast Thou brought me forth? I expire, and the eye doth not see me.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I had not been, I am, From the belly to the grave I am brought,
speaker: Narrator

text: Are not my days few? Cease then, and put from me, And I brighten up a little,
speaker: Narrator

text: Before I go, and return not, Unto a land of darkness and death-shade,
speaker: Narrator

text: A land of obscurity as thick darkness, Death-shade -- and no order, And the shining [is] as thick darkness.'
speaker: Narrator

text: And Zophar the Naamathite answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Is a multitude of words not answered? And is a man of lips justified?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy devices make men keep silent, Thou scornest, and none is causing blushing!
speaker: Narrator

text: And thou sayest, `Pure [is] my discourse, And clean I have been in Thine eyes.'
speaker: Narrator

text: And yet, O that God had spoken! And doth open His lips with thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: And declare to thee secrets of wisdom, For counsel hath foldings. And know thou that God forgetteth for thee, [Some] of thine iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: By searching dost thou find out God? Unto perfection find out the Mighty One?
speaker: Narrator

text: Heights of the heavens! -- what dost thou? Deeper than Sheol! -- what knowest thou?
speaker: Narrator

text: Longer than earth [is] its measure, And broader than the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: If He pass on, and shut up, and assemble, Who then dost reverse it?
speaker: Narrator

text: For he hath known men of vanity, And He seeth iniquity, And one doth not consider [it]!
speaker: Narrator

text: And empty man is bold, And the colt of a wild ass man is born.
speaker: Narrator

text: If thou -- thou hast prepared thy heart, And hast spread out unto Him thy hands,
speaker: Narrator

text: If iniquity [is] in thy hand, put it far off, And let not perverseness dwell in thy tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: For then thou liftest up thy face from blemish, And thou hast been firm, and fearest not.
speaker: Narrator

text: For thou dost forget misery, As waters passed away thou rememberest.
speaker: Narrator

text: And above the noon doth age rise, Thou fliest -- as the morning thou art.
speaker: Narrator

text: And thou hast trusted because their is hope, And searched -- in confidence thou liest down,
speaker: Narrator

text: And thou hast rested, And none is causing trembling, And many have entreated thy face;
speaker: Narrator

text: And the eyes of the wicked are consumed, And refuge hath perished from them, And their hope [is] a breathing out of soul!
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Truly -- ye [are] the people, And with you doth wisdom die.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also have a heart like you, I am not fallen more than you, And with whom is there not like these?
speaker: Narrator

text: A laughter to his friend I am: `He calleth to God, and He answereth him,' A laughter [is] the perfect righteous one.
speaker: Narrator

text: A torch -- despised in the thoughts of the secure Is prepared for those sliding with the feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: At peace are the tents of spoilers, And those provoking God have confidence, He into whose hand God hath brought.
speaker: Narrator

text: And yet, ask, I pray thee, [One of] the beasts, and it doth shew thee, And a fowl of the heavens, And it doth declare to thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or talk to the earth, and it sheweth thee, And fishes of the sea recount to thee:
speaker: Narrator

text: `Who hath not known in all these, That the hand of Jehovah hath done this?
speaker: Narrator

text: In whose hand [is] the breath of every living thing, And the spirit of all flesh of man.'
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth not the ear try words? And the palate taste food for itself?
speaker: Narrator

text: With the very aged [is] wisdom, And [with] length of days understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: With Him [are] wisdom and might, To him [are] counsel and understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, He breaketh down, and it is not built up, He shutteth against a man, And it is not opened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, He keepeth in the waters, and they are dried up, And he sendeth them forth, And they overturn the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: With Him [are] strength and wisdom, His the deceived and deceiver.
speaker: Narrator

text: Causing counsellors to go away a spoil, And judges He maketh foolish.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bands of kings He hath opened, And He bindeth a girdle on their loins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Causing ministers to go away a spoil And strong ones He overthroweth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Turning aside the lip of the stedfast, And the reason of the aged He taketh away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pouring contempt upon princes, And the girdle of the mighty He made feeble.
speaker: Narrator

text: Removing deep things out of darkness, And He bringeth out to light death-shade.
speaker: Narrator

text: Magnifying the nations, and He destroyeth them, Spreading out the nations, and He quieteth them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Turning aside the heart Of the heads of the people of the land, And he causeth them to wander In vacancy -- no way!
speaker: Narrator

text: They feel darkness, and not light, He causeth them to wander as a drunkard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, all -- hath mine eye seen, Heard hath mine ear, and it attendeth to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: According to your knowledge I have known -- also I. I am not fallen more than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet I for the Mighty One do speak, And to argue for God I delight.
speaker: Narrator

text: And yet, ye [are] forgers of falsehood, Physicians of nought -- all of you,
speaker: Narrator

text: O that ye would keep perfectly silent, And it would be to you for wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear, I pray you, my argument, And to the pleadings of my lips attend,
speaker: Narrator

text: For God do ye speak perverseness? And for Him do ye speak deceit?
speaker: Narrator

text: His face do ye accept, if for God ye strive?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is [it] good that He doth search you, If, as one mocketh at a man, ye mock at Him?
speaker: Narrator

text: He doth surely reprove you, if in secret ye accept faces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth not His excellency terrify you? And His dread fall upon you?
speaker: Narrator

text: Your remembrances [are] similes of ashes, For high places of clay your heights.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep silent from me, and I speak, And pass over me doth what?
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore do I take my flesh in my teeth? And my soul put in my hand?
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, He doth slay me -- I wait not! Only, my ways unto His face I argue.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also -- He [is] to me for salvation, For the profane cometh not before Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear ye diligently my word, And my declaration with your ears.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, I pray you, I have set in order the cause, I have known that I am righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who [is] he that doth strive with me? For now I keep silent and gasp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only two things, O God, do with me: Then from Thy face I am not hidden.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy hand put far off from me, And Thy terror let not terrify me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And call Thou, and I -- I answer, Or -- I speak, and answer Thou me.
speaker: Narrator

text: How many iniquities and sins have I? My transgression and my sin let me know.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why dost Thou hide Thy face? And reckonest me for an enemy to Thee?
speaker: Narrator

text: A leaf driven away dost Thou terrify? And the dry stubble dost Thou pursue?
speaker: Narrator

text: For Thou writest against me bitter things, And causest me to possess iniquities of my youth:
speaker: Narrator

text: And puttest in the stocks my feet, And observest all my paths, On the roots of my feet Thou settest a print,
speaker: Narrator

text: And he, as a rotten thing, weareth away, As a garment hath a moth consumed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Man, born of woman! Of few days, and full of trouble!
speaker: Narrator

text: As a flower he hath gone forth, and is cut off, And he fleeth as a shadow and standeth not.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also -- on this Thou hast opened Thine eyes, And dost bring me into judgment with Thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who giveth a clean thing out of an unclean? not one.
speaker: Narrator

text: If determined are his days, The number of his months [are] with Thee, His limit Thou hast made, And he passeth not over;
speaker: Narrator

text: Look away from off him that he may cease, Till he enjoy as an hireling his day.
speaker: Narrator

text: For there is of a tree hope, if it be cut down, That again it doth change, That its tender branch doth not cease.
speaker: Narrator

text: If its root becometh old in the earth, And its stem doth die in the dust,
speaker: Narrator

text: From the fragrance of water it doth flourish, And hath made a crop as a plant.
speaker: Narrator

text: And a man dieth, and becometh weak, And man expireth, and where [is] he?
speaker: Narrator

text: Waters have gone away from a sea, And a river becometh waste and dry.
speaker: Narrator

text: And man hath lain down, and riseth not, Till the wearing out of the heavens they awake not, Nor are roused from their sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text: O that in Sheol Thou wouldst conceal me, Hide me till the turning of Thine anger, Set for me a limit, and remember me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man dieth -- doth he revive? All days of my warfare I wait, till my change come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou dost call, and I -- I answer Thee; To the work of Thy hands Thou hast desire.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, my steps Thou numberest, Thou dost not watch over my sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sealed up in a bag [is] my transgression, And Thou sewest up mine iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: And yet, a falling mountain wasteth away, And a rock is removed from its place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stones have waters worn away, Their outpourings wash away the dust of earth, And the hope of man Thou hast destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou prevailest [over] him for ever, and he goeth, He is changing his countenance, And Thou sendest him away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Honoured are his sons, and he knoweth not; And they are little, and he attendeth not to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only -- his flesh for him is pained, And his soul for him doth mourn.'
speaker: Narrator

text: And Eliphaz the Temanite answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth a wise man answer [with] vain knowledge? And fill [with] an east wind his belly?
speaker: Narrator

text: To reason with a word not useful? And speeches -- no profit in them?
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, thou dost make reverence void, And dost diminish meditation before God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For thy mouth teacheth thine iniquity, And thou chooseth the tongue of the subtile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy mouth declareth thee wicked, and not I, And thy lips testify against thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first man art thou born? And before the heights wast thou formed?
speaker: Narrator

text: Of the secret counsel of God dost thou hear? And withdrawest thou unto thee wisdom?
speaker: Narrator

text: What hast thou known, and we know not? Understandest thou -- and it is not with us?
speaker: Narrator

text: Both the gray-headed And the very aged [are] among us -- Greater than thy father [in] days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Too few for thee are the comforts of God? And a gentle word [is] with thee,
speaker: Narrator

text: What -- doth thine heart take thee away? And what -- are thine eyes high?
speaker: Narrator

text: For thou turnest against God thy spirit? And hast brought out words from thy mouth:
speaker: Narrator

text: What [is] man that he is pure, And that he is righteous, one born of woman?
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, in His holy ones He putteth no credence, And the heavens have not been pure in His eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also -- surely abominable and filthy Is man drinking as water perverseness.
speaker: Narrator

text: I shew thee -- hearken to me -- And this I have seen and declare:
speaker: Narrator

text: Which the wise declare -- And have not hid -- from their fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: To them alone was the land given, And a stranger passed not over into their midst:
speaker: Narrator

text: `All days of the wicked he is paining himself, And few years have been laid up for the terrible one.
speaker: Narrator

text: A fearful voice [is] in his ears, In peace doth a destroyer come to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He believeth not to return from darkness, And watched [is] he for the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is wandering for bread -- `Where [is] it?' He hath known that ready at his hand Is a day of darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Terrify him do adversity and distress, They prevail over him As a king ready for a boaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he stretched out against God his hand, And against the Mighty he maketh himself mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: He runneth unto Him with a neck, With thick bosses of his shields.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he hath covered his face with his fat, And maketh vigour over [his] confidence.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he inhabiteth cities cut off, houses not dwelt in, That have been ready to become heaps.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is not rich, nor doth his wealth rise, Nor doth he stretch out on earth their continuance.
speaker: Narrator

text: He turneth not aside from darkness, His tender branch doth a flame dry up, And he turneth aside at the breath of His mouth!
speaker: Narrator

text: Let him not put credence in vanity, He hath been deceived, For vanity is his recompence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not in his day is it completed, And his bending branch is not green.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shaketh off as a vine his unripe fruit, And casteth off as an olive his blossom.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the company of the profane [is] gloomy, And fire hath consumed tents of bribery.
speaker: Narrator

text: To conceive misery, and to bear iniquity, Even their heart doth prepare deceit.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: I have heard many such things, Miserable comforters [are] ye all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is there an end to words of wind? Or what doth embolden thee that thou answerest?
speaker: Narrator

text: I also, like you, might speak, If your soul were in my soul's stead. I might join against you with words, And nod at you with my head.
speaker: Narrator

text: I might harden you with my mouth, And the moving of my lips might be sparing.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I speak, my pain is not restrained, And I cease -- what goeth from me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Only, now, it hath wearied me; Thou hast desolated all my company,
speaker: Narrator

text: And Thou dost loathe me, For a witness it hath been, And rise up against me doth my failure, In my face it testifieth.
speaker: Narrator

text: His anger hath torn, and he hateth me, He hath gnashed at me with his teeth, My adversary sharpeneth his eyes for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have gaped on me with their mouth, In reproach they have smitten my cheeks, Together against me they set themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: God shutteth me up unto the perverse, And to the hands of the wicked turneth me over.
speaker: Narrator

text: At ease I have been, and he breaketh me, And he hath laid hold on my neck, And he breaketh me in pieces, And he raiseth me to him for a mark.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go round against me do his archers. He splitteth my reins, and spareth not, He poureth out to the earth my gall.
speaker: Narrator

text: He breaketh me -- breach upon breach, He runneth upon me as a mighty one.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sackcloth I have sewed on my skin, And have rolled in the dust my horn.
speaker: Narrator

text: My face is foul with weeping, And on mine eyelids [is] death-shade.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not for violence in my hands, And my prayer [is] pure.
speaker: Narrator

text: O earth, do not thou cover my blood! And let there not be a place for my cry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, now, lo, in the heavens [is] my witness, And my testifier in the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: My interpreter [is] my friend, Unto God hath mine eye dropped:
speaker: Narrator

text: And he reasoneth for a man with God, And a son of man for his friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a few years do come, Then a path I return not do I go.
speaker: Narrator

text: My spirit hath been destroyed, My days extinguished -- graves [are] for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If not -- mockeries [are] with me. And in their provocations mine eye lodgeth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Place, I pray Thee, my pledge with Thee; Who is he that striketh hand with me?
speaker: Narrator

text: For their heart Thou hast hidden From understanding, Therefore Thou dost not exalt them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a portion he sheweth friendship, And the eyes of his sons are consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he set me up for a proverb of the peoples, And a wonder before them I am.
speaker: Narrator

text: And dim from sorrow is mine eye, And my members as a shadow all of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Astonished are the upright at this, And the innocent against the profane Stirreth himself up.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the righteous layeth hold [on] his way, And the clean of hands addeth strength, And -- dumb are they all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Return, and come in, I pray you, And I find not among you a wise man.
speaker: Narrator

text: My days have passed by, My devices have been broken off, The possessions of my heart!
speaker: Narrator

text: Night for day they appoint, Light [is] near because of darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I wait -- Sheol [is] my house, In darkness I have spread out my couch.
speaker: Narrator

text: To corruption I have called: -- `Thou [art] my father.' `My mother' and `my sister' -- to the worm.
speaker: Narrator

text: And where [is] now my hope? Yea, my hope, who doth behold it?
speaker: Narrator

text: [To] the parts of Sheol ye go down, If together on the dust we may rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Bildad the Shuhite answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: When do ye set an end to words? Consider ye, and afterwards do we speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore have we been reckoned as cattle? We have been defiled in your eyes!
speaker: Narrator

text: (He is tearing himself in his anger.) For thy sake is earth forsaken? And removed is a rock from its place?
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, the light of the wicked is extinguished. And there doth not shine a spark of his fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: The light hath been dark in his tent, And his lamp over him is extinguished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Straitened are the steps of his strength, And cast him down doth his own counsel.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he is sent into a net by his own feet, And on a snare he doth walk habitually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seize on the heel doth a gin, Prevail over him do the designing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hidden in the earth is his cord, And his trap on the path.
speaker: Narrator

text: Round about terrified him have terrors, And they have scattered him -- at his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hungry is his sorrow, And calamity is ready at his side.
speaker: Narrator

text: It consumeth the parts of his skin, Consume his parts doth death's first-born.
speaker: Narrator

text: Drawn from his tent is his confidence, And it causeth him to step to the king of terrors.
speaker: Narrator

text: It dwelleth in his tent -- out of his provender, Scattered over his habitation is sulphur.
speaker: Narrator

text: From beneath his roots are dried up, And from above cut off is his crop.
speaker: Narrator

text: His memorial hath perished from the land, And he hath no name on the street.
speaker: Narrator

text: They thrust him from light unto darkness, And from the habitable earth cast him out.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath no continuator, Nor successor among his people, And none is remaining in his dwellings.
speaker: Narrator

text: At this day westerns have been astonished And easterns have taken fright.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only these [are] tabernacles of the perverse, And this the place God hath not known.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Till when do ye afflict my soul, And bruise me with words?
speaker: Narrator

text: These ten times ye put me to shame, ye blush not. Ye make yourselves strange to me --
speaker: Narrator

text: And also -- truly, I have erred, With me doth my error remain.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, truly, over me ye magnify yourselves, And decide against me my reproach;
speaker: Narrator

text: Know now, that God turned me upside down, And His net against me hath set round,
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, I cry out -- violence, and am not answered, I cry aloud, and there is no judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: My way He hedged up, and I pass not over, And on my paths darkness He placeth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mine honour from off me He hath stripped, And He turneth the crown from my head.
speaker: Narrator

text: He breaketh me down round about, and I go, And removeth like a tree my hope.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He kindleth against me His anger, And reckoneth me to Him as His adversaries.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come in do His troops together, And they raise up against me their way, And encamp round about my tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brethren from me He hath put far off, And mine acquaintances surely Have been estranged from me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ceased have my neighbours And my familiar friends have forgotten me,
speaker: Narrator

text: Sojourners of my house and my maids, For a stranger reckon me: An alien I have been in their eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: To my servant I have called, And he doth not answer, With my mouth I make supplication to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: My spirit is strange to my wife, And my favours to the sons of my [mother's] womb.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also sucklings have despised me, I rise, and they speak against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abominate me do all the men of my counsel, And those I have loved, Have been turned against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: To my skin and to my flesh Cleaved hath my bone, And I deliver myself with the skin of my teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pity me, pity me, ye my friends, For the hand of God hath stricken against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do you pursue me as God? And with my flesh are not satisfied?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who doth grant now, That my words may be written? Who doth grant that in a book they may be graven?
speaker: Narrator

text: With a pen of iron and lead -- For ever in a rock they may be hewn.
speaker: Narrator

text: That -- I have known my Redeemer, The Living and the Last, For the dust he doth rise.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after my skin hath compassed this [body], Then from my flesh I see God:
speaker: Narrator

text: Whom I -- I see on my side, And mine eyes have beheld, and not a stranger, Consumed have been my reins in my bosom.
speaker: Narrator

text: But ye say, `Why do we pursue after him?' And the root of the matter hath been found in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be ye afraid because of the sword, For furious [are] the punishments of the sword, That ye may know that [there is] a judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Zophar the Naamathite answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore my thoughts cause me to answer, And because of my sensations in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The chastisement of my shame I hear, And the spirit of mine understanding Doth cause me to answer:
speaker: Narrator

text: This hast thou known from antiquity? Since the placing of man on earth?
speaker: Narrator

text: That the singing of the wicked [is] short, And the joy of the profane for a moment,
speaker: Narrator

text: Though his excellency go up to the heavens, And his head against a cloud he strike --
speaker: Narrator

text: As his own dung for ever he doth perish, His beholders say: `Where [is] he?'
speaker: Narrator

text: As a dream he fleeth, and they find him not, And he is driven away as a vision of the night,
speaker: Narrator

text: The eye hath not seen him, and addeth not. And not again doth his place behold him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons do the poor oppress, And his hands give back his wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text: His bones have been full of his youth, And with him on the dust it lieth down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though he doth sweeten evil in his mouth, Doth hide it under his tongue,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hath pity on it, and doth not forsake it, And keep it back in the midst of his palate,
speaker: Narrator

text: His food in his bowels is turned, The bitterness of asps [is] in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wealth he hath swallowed, and doth vomit it. From his belly God driveth it out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gall of asps he sucketh, Slay him doth the tongue of a viper.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looketh not on rivulets, Flowing of brooks of honey and butter.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is giving back [what] he laboured for, And doth not consume [it]; As a bulwark [is] his exchange, and he exults not.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he oppressed -- he forsook the poor, A house he hath taken violently away, And he doth not build it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he hath not known ease in his belly. With his desirable thing he delivereth not himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is not a remnant to his food, Therefore his good doth not stay.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fulness of his sufficiency he is straitened. Every perverse hand doth meet him.
speaker: Narrator

text: It cometh to pass, at the filling of his belly, He sendeth forth against him The fierceness of His anger, Yea, He raineth on him in his eating.
speaker: Narrator

text: He fleeth from an iron weapon, Pass through him doth a bow of brass.
speaker: Narrator

text: One hath drawn, And it cometh out from the body, And a glittering weapon from his gall proceedeth. On him [are] terrors.
speaker: Narrator

text: All darkness is hid for his treasures, Consume him doth a fire not blown, Broken is the remnant in his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Reveal do the heavens his iniquity, And earth is raising itself against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remove doth the increase of his house, Poured forth in a day of His anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: This [is] the portion of a wicked man from God. And an inheritance appointed him by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear ye diligently my word, And this is your consolation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bear with me, and I speak, And after my speaking -- ye may deride.
speaker: Narrator

text: I -- to man [is] my complaint? and if [so], wherefore May not my temper become short?
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn unto me, and be astonished, And put hand to mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, if I have remembered, then I have been troubled. And my flesh hath taken fright.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore do the wicked live? They have become old, Yea, they have been mighty in wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their seed is established, Before their face with them, And their offspring before their eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their houses [are] peace without fear, Nor [is] a rod of God upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text: His bullock hath eaten corn, and doth not loath. His cow bringeth forth safely, And doth not miscarry.
speaker: Narrator

text: They send forth as a flock their sucklings, And their children skip,
speaker: Narrator

text: They lift [themselves] up at timbrel and harp, And rejoice at the sound of an organ.
speaker: Narrator

text: They wear out in good their days, And in a moment [to] Sheol go down.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they say to God, `Turn aside from us, And the knowledge of Thy ways We have not desired.
speaker: Narrator

text: What [is] the Mighty One that we serve Him? And what do we profit when we meet with Him?'
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, not in their hand [is] their good, (The counsel of the wicked Hath been far from me.)
speaker: Narrator

text: How oft is the lamp of the wicked extinguished, And come on them doth their calamity? Pangs He apportioneth in His anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are as straw before wind, And as chaff a hurricane hath stolen away,
speaker: Narrator

text: God layeth up for his sons his sorrow, He giveth recompense unto him -- and he knoweth.
speaker: Narrator

text: His own eyes see his destruction, And of the wrath of the Mighty he drinketh.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what [is] his delight in his house after him, And the number of his months cut off?
speaker: Narrator

text: To God doth [one] teach knowledge, And He the high doth judge?
speaker: Narrator

text: This [one] dieth in his perfect strength, Wholly at ease and quiet.
speaker: Narrator

text: His breasts have been full of milk, And marrow his bones doth moisten.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this [one] dieth with a bitter soul, And have not eaten with gladness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Together -- on the dust they lie down, And the worm doth cover them over.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, I have known your thoughts, And the devices against me ye do wrongfully.
speaker: Narrator

text: For ye say, `Where [is] the house of the noble? And where the tent -- The tabernacles of the wicked?'
speaker: Narrator

text: Have ye not asked those passing by the way? And their signs do ye not know?
speaker: Narrator

text: That to a day of calamity is the wicked spared. To a day of wrath they are brought.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who doth declare to his face his way? And [for] that which he hath done, Who doth give recompence to him?
speaker: Narrator

text: And he -- to the graves he is brought. And over the heap a watch is kept.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sweet to him have been the clods of the valley, And after him every man he draweth, And before him there is no numbering.
speaker: Narrator

text: And how do ye comfort me [with] vanity, And in your answers hath been left trespass?
speaker: Narrator

text: And Eliphaz the Temanite answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: To God is a man profitable, Because a wise man to himself is profitable?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it a delight to the Mighty One That thou art righteous? is it gain, That thou makest perfect thy ways?
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of thy reverence Doth He reason [with] thee? He entereth with thee into judgment:
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not thy wickedness abundant? And there is no end to thine iniquities.
speaker: Narrator

text: For thou takest a pledge of thy brother for nought, And the garments of the naked Thou dost strip off.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou causest not the weary to drink water, And from the hungry thou withholdest bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: As to the man of arm -- he hath the earth, And the accepted of face -- he dwelleth in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Widows thou hast sent away empty, And the arms of the fatherless are bruised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore round about thee [are] snares, And trouble thee doth fear suddenly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or darkness -- thou dost not see, And abundance of waters doth cover thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not God high [in] heaven? And see the summit of the stars, That they are high.
speaker: Narrator

text: And thou hast said, `What -- hath God known? Through thickness doth He judge?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thick clouds [are] a secret place to Him, And He doth not see;' And the circle of the heavens He walketh habitually,
speaker: Narrator

text: The path of the age dost thou observe, That men of iniquity have trodden?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who have been cut down unexpectedly, A flood is poured out on their foundation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those saying to God, `Turn aside from us,' And what doth the Mighty One to them?
speaker: Narrator

text: And he hath filled their houses [with] good: (And the counsel of the wicked Hath been far from me.)
speaker: Narrator

text: See do the righteous and they rejoice, And the innocent mocketh at them,
speaker: Narrator

text: `Surely our substance hath not been cut off, And their excellency hath fire consumed.'
speaker: Narrator

text: Acquaint thyself, I pray thee, with Him, And be at peace, Thereby thine increase [is] good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Receive, I pray thee, from His mouth a law, And set His sayings in thy heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: If thou dost return unto the Mighty Thou art built up, Thou puttest iniquity far from thy tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: So as to set on the dust a defence, And on a rock of the valleys a covering.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Mighty hath been thy defence, And silver [is] strength to thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: For then on the Mighty thou delightest thyself, And dost lift up unto God thy face,
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou dost make supplication unto Him, And He doth hear thee, And thy vows thou completest.
speaker: Narrator

text: And thou decreest a saying, And it is established to thee, And on thy ways hath light shone.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they have made low, And thou sayest, `Lift up.' And the bowed down of eyes he saveth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He delivereth the not innocent, Yea, he hath been delivered By the cleanness of thy hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Also -- to-day [is] my complaint bitter, My hand hath been heavy because of my sighing.
speaker: Narrator

text: O that I had known -- and I find Him, I come in unto His seat,
speaker: Narrator

text: I arrange before Him the cause, And my mouth fill [with] arguments.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know the words He doth answer me, And understand what He saith to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the abundance of power doth He strive with me? No! surely He putteth [it] in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: There the upright doth reason with Him, And I escape for ever from my judge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, forward I go -- and He is not, And backward -- and I perceive him not.
speaker: Narrator

text: [To] the left in His working -- and I see not, He is covered [on] the right, and I behold not.
speaker: Narrator

text: For He hath known the way with me, He hath tried me -- as gold I go forth.
speaker: Narrator

text: On His step hath my foot laid hold, His way I have kept, and turn not aside,
speaker: Narrator

text: The command of His lips, and I depart not. Above my allotted portion I have laid up The sayings of His mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He [is] in one [mind], And who doth turn Him back? And His soul hath desired -- and He doth [it].
speaker: Narrator

text: For He doth complete my portion, And many such things [are] with Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, from His presence I am troubled, I consider, and am afraid of Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God hath made my heart soft, And the Mighty hath troubled me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I have not been cut off before darkness, And before me He covered thick darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore from the Mighty One Times have not been hidden, And those knowing Him have not seen His days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The borders they reach, A drove they have taken violently away, Yea, they do evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ass of the fatherless they lead away, They take in pledge the ox of the widow,
speaker: Narrator

text: They turn aside the needy from the way, Together have hid the poor of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, wild asses in a wilderness, They have gone out about their work, Seeking early for prey, A mixture for himself -- food for young ones.
speaker: Narrator

text: In a field his provender they reap, And the vineyard of the wicked they glean.
speaker: Narrator

text: The naked they cause to lodge Without clothing. And there is no covering in the cold.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the inundation of hills they are wet, And without a refuge -- have embraced a rock.
speaker: Narrator

text: They take violently away From the breast the orphan, And on the poor they lay a pledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Naked, they have gone without clothing, And hungry -- have taken away a sheaf.
speaker: Narrator

text: Between their walls they make oil, Wine-presses they have trodden, and thirst.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of enmity men do groan, And the soul of pierced ones doth cry, And God doth not give praise.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have been among rebellious ones of light, They have not discerned His ways, Nor abode in His paths.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the light doth the murderer rise, He doth slay the poor and needy, And in the night he is as a thief.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the eye of an adulterer Hath observed the twilight, Saying, `No eye doth behold me.' And he putteth the face in secret.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath dug in the darkness -- houses; By day they shut themselves up, They have not known light.
speaker: Narrator

text: When together, morning [is] to them death shade, When he discerneth the terrors of death shade.
speaker: Narrator

text: Light he [is] on the face of the waters, Vilified is their portion in the earth, He turneth not the way of vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text: Drought -- also heat -- consume snow-waters, Sheol [those who] have sinned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Forget him doth the womb, Sweeten [on] him doth the worm, No more is he remembered, And broken as a tree is wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Treating evil the barren [who] beareth not, And [to] the widow he doth no good,
speaker: Narrator

text: And hath drawn the mighty by his power, He riseth, and none believeth in life.
speaker: Narrator

text: He giveth to him confidence, and he is supported, And his eyes [are] on their ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: High they were [for] a little, and they are not, And they have been brought low. As all [others] they are shut up, And as the head of an ear of corn cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if not now, who doth prove me a liar, And doth make of nothing my word?
speaker: Narrator

text: And Bildad the Shuhite answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: The rule and fear [are] with Him, Making peace in His high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is their [any] number to His troops? And on whom ariseth not His light?
speaker: Narrator

text: And what? is man righteous with God? And what? is he pure -- born of a woman?
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo -- unto the moon, and it shineth not, And stars have not been pure in His eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much less man -- a grub, And the son of man -- a worm!
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: What -- thou hast helped the powerless, Saved an arm not strong!
speaker: Narrator

text: What -- thou hast given counsel to the unwise, And wise plans in abundance made known.
speaker: Narrator

text: With whom hast thou declared words? And whose breath came forth from thee?
speaker: Narrator

text: The Rephaim are formed, Beneath the waters, also their inhabitants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Naked [is] Sheol over-against Him, And there is no covering to destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stretching out the north over desolation, Hanging the earth upon nothing,
speaker: Narrator

text: Binding up the waters in His thick clouds, And the cloud is not rent under them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Taking hold of the face of the throne, Spreading over it His cloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: A limit He hath placed on the waters, Unto the boundary of light with darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pillars of the heavens do tremble, And they wonder because of His rebuke.
speaker: Narrator

text: By His power He hath quieted the sea, And by His understanding smitten the proud.
speaker: Narrator

text: By His Spirit the heavens He beautified, Formed hath His hand the fleeing serpent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, these [are] the borders of His way, And how little a matter is heard of Him, And the thunder of His might Who doth understand?
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job addeth to lift up his simile, and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: God liveth! He turned aside my judgment, And the Mighty -- He made my soul bitter.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all the while my breath [is] in me, And the spirit of God in my nostrils.
speaker: Narrator

text: My lips do not speak perverseness, And my tongue doth not utter deceit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pollution to me -- if I justify you, Till I expire I turn not aside mine integrity from me.
speaker: Narrator

text: On my righteousness I have laid hold, And I do not let it go, My heart doth not reproach me while I live.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the wicked is my enemy, And my withstander as the perverse.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what [is] the hope of the profane, When He doth cut off? When God doth cast off his soul?
speaker: Narrator

text: His cry doth God hear, When distress cometh on him?
speaker: Narrator

text: On the Mighty doth he delight himself? Call God at all times?
speaker: Narrator

text: I shew you by the hand of God, That which [is] with the Mighty I hide not.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, ye -- all of you -- have seen, And why [is] this -- ye are altogether vain?
speaker: Narrator

text: This [is] the portion of wicked man with God, And the inheritance of terrible ones From the Mighty they receive.
speaker: Narrator

text: If his sons multiply -- for them [is] a sword. And his offspring [are] not satisfied [with] bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: His remnant in death are buried, And his widows do not weep.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he heap up as dust silver, And as clay prepare clothing,
speaker: Narrator

text: He prepareth -- and the righteous putteth [it] on, And the silver the innocent doth apportion.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath built as a moth his house, And as a booth a watchman hath made.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rich he lieth down, and he is not gathered, His eyes he hath opened, and he is not.
speaker: Narrator

text: Overtake him as waters do terrors, By night stolen him away hath a whirlwind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take him up doth an east wind, and he goeth, And it frighteneth him from his place,
speaker: Narrator

text: And it casteth at him, and doth not spare, From its hand he diligently fleeth.
speaker: Narrator

text: It clappeth at him its hands, And it hisseth at him from his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely there is for silver a source, And a place for the gold they refine;
speaker: Narrator

text: Iron from the dust is taken, And [from] the firm stone brass.
speaker: Narrator

text: An end hath he set to darkness, And to all perfection he is searching, A stone of darkness and death-shade.
speaker: Narrator

text: A stream hath broken out from a sojourner, Those forgotten of the foot, They were low, from man they wandered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth! from it cometh forth bread, And its under-part is turned like fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: A place of the sapphire [are] its stones, And it hath dust of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: A path -- not known it hath a ravenous fowl, Nor scorched it hath an eye of the kite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nor trodden it have the sons of pride, Not passed over it hath the fierce lion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Against the flint he sent forth his hand, He overturned from the root mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among rocks, brooks he hath cleaved, And every precious thing hath his eye seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: From overflowing floods he hath bound, And the hidden thing bringeth out [to] light.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the wisdom -- whence is it found? And where [is] this, the place of understanding?
speaker: Narrator

text: Man hath not known its arrangement, Nor is it found in the land of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: The deep hath said, `It [is] not in me,' And the sea hath said, `It is not with me.'
speaker: Narrator

text: Gold is not given for it, Nor is silver weighed -- its price.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not valued with pure gold of Ophir, With precious onyx and sapphire,
speaker: Narrator

text: Not equal it do gold and crystal, Nor [is] its exchange a vessel of fine gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Corals and pearl are not remembered, The acquisition of wisdom [is] above rubies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not equal it doth the topaz of Cush, With pure gold it is not valued.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the wisdom -- whence doth it come? And where [is] this, the place of understanding?
speaker: Narrator

text: It hath been hid from the eyes of all living. And from the fowl of the heavens It hath been hidden.
speaker: Narrator

text: Destruction and death have said: `With our ears we have heard its fame.'
speaker: Narrator

text: God hath understood its way, And He hath known its place.
speaker: Narrator

text: For He to the ends of the earth doth look, Under the whole heavens He doth see,
speaker: Narrator

text: To make for the wind a weight, And the waters He meted out in measure.
speaker: Narrator

text: In His making for the rain a limit, And a way for the brightness of the voices,
speaker: Narrator

text: Then He hath seen and declareth it, He hath prepared it, and also searched it out,
speaker: Narrator

text: And He saith to man: -- `Lo, fear of the Lord, that [is] wisdom, And to turn from evil [is] understanding.'
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job addeth to lift up his simile, and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Who doth make me as [in] months past, As [in] the days of God's preserving me?
speaker: Narrator

text: In His causing His lamp to shine on my head, By His light I walk [through] darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: As I have been in days of my maturity, And the counsel of God upon my tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: When yet the Mighty One [is] with me. Round about me -- my young ones,
speaker: Narrator

text: When washing my goings with butter, And the firm rock [is] with me rivulets of oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I go out to the gate by the city, In a broad place I prepare my seat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seen me have youths, and they, been hidden, And the aged have risen -- they stood up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Princes have kept in words, And a hand they place on their mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The voice of leaders hath been hidden, And their tongue to the palate hath cleaved.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the ear heard, and declareth me happy, And the eye hath seen, and testifieth [to] me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I deliver the afflicted who is crying, And the fatherless who hath no helper.
speaker: Narrator

text: The blessing of the perishing cometh on me, And the heart of the widow I cause to sing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Righteousness I have put on, and it clotheth me, As a robe and a diadem my justice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eyes I have been to the blind, And feet to the lame [am] I.
speaker: Narrator

text: A father I [am] to the needy, And the cause I have not known I search out.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I break the jaw-teeth of the perverse, And from his teeth I cast away prey.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I say, `With my nest I expire, And as the sand I multiply days.'
speaker: Narrator

text: My root is open unto the waters, And dew doth lodge on my branch.
speaker: Narrator

text: My honour [is] fresh with me, And my bow in my hand is renewed.
speaker: Narrator

text: To me they have hearkened, Yea, they wait, and are silent for my counsel.
speaker: Narrator

text: After my word they change not, And on them doth my speech drop,
speaker: Narrator

text: And they wait as [for] rain for me, And their mouth they have opened wide [As] for the latter rain.
speaker: Narrator

text: I laugh unto them -- they give no credence, And the light of my face cause not to fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: I choose their way, and sit head, And I dwell as a king in a troop, When mourners he doth comfort.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, laughed at me, Have the younger in days than I, Whose fathers I have loathed to set With the dogs of my flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also -- the power of their hands, why [is it] to me? On them hath old age perished.
speaker: Narrator

text: With want and with famine gloomy, Those fleeing to a dry place, Formerly a desolation and waste,
speaker: Narrator

text: Those cropping mallows near a shrub, And broom-roots [is] their food.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the midst they are cast out, (They shout against them as a thief),
speaker: Narrator

text: In a frightful place of valleys to dwell, Holes of earth and clefts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among shrubs they do groan, Under nettles they are gathered together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sons of folly -- even sons without name, They have been smitten from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, their song I have been, And I am to them for a byword.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have abominated me, They have kept far from me, And from before me have not spared to spit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because His cord He loosed and afflicteth me, And the bridle from before me, They have cast away.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the right hand doth a brood arise, My feet they have cast away, And they raise up against me, Their paths of calamity.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have broken down my path, By my calamity they profit, `He hath no helper.'
speaker: Narrator

text: As a wide breach they come, Under the desolation have rolled themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath turned against me terrors, It pursueth as the wind mine abundance, And as a thick cloud, Hath my safety passed away.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, in me my soul poureth itself out, Seize me do days of affliction.
speaker: Narrator

text: At night my bone hath been pierced in me, And mine eyelids do not lie down.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the abundance of power, Is my clothing changed, As the mouth of my coat it doth gird me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Casting me into mire, And I am become like dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I cry unto Thee, And Thou dost not answer me, I have stood, and Thou dost consider me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou art turned to be fierce to me, With the strength of Thy hand, Thou oppresest me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou dost lift me up, On the wind Thou dost cause me to ride, And Thou meltest -- Thou levellest me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I have known To death Thou dost bring me back, And [to] the house appointed for all living.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely not against the heap Doth He send forth the hand, Though in its ruin they have safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: Did not I weep for him whose day is hard? Grieved hath my soul for the needy.
speaker: Narrator

text: When good I expected, then cometh evil, And I wait for light, and darkness cometh.
speaker: Narrator

text: My bowels have boiled, and have not ceased, Gone before me have days of affliction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mourning I have gone without the sun, I have risen, in an assembly I cry.
speaker: Narrator

text: A brother I have been to dragons, And a companion to daughters of the ostrich.
speaker: Narrator

text: My skin hath been black upon me, And my bone hath burned from heat,
speaker: Narrator

text: And my harp doth become mourning, And my organ the sound of weeping.
speaker: Narrator

text: A covenant I made for mine eyes, And what -- do I attend to a virgin?
speaker: Narrator
