text: And what [is] the portion of God from above? And the inheritance of the Mighty from the heights?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not calamity to the perverse? And strangeness to workers of iniquity?
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth not He see my ways, And all my steps number?
speaker: Narrator

text: If I have walked with vanity, And my foot doth hasten to deceit,
speaker: Narrator

text: He doth weigh me in righteous balances, And God doth know my integrity.
speaker: Narrator

text: If my step doth turn aside from the way, And after mine eyes hath my heart gone, And to my hands cleaved hath blemish,
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me sow -- and another eat, And my products let be rooted out.
speaker: Narrator

text: If my heart hath been enticed by woman, And by the opening of my neighbour I laid wait,
speaker: Narrator

text: Grind to another let my wife, And over her let others bend.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it [is] a wicked thing, and a judicial iniquity;
speaker: Narrator

text: For a fire it [is], to destruction it consumeth, And among all mine increase doth take root,
speaker: Narrator

text: If I despise the cause of my man-servant, And of my handmaid, In their contending with me,
speaker: Narrator

text: Then what do I do when God ariseth? And when He doth inspect, What do I answer Him?
speaker: Narrator

text: Did not He that made me in the womb make him? Yea, prepare us in the womb doth One.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I withhold from pleasure the poor, And the eyes of the widow do consume,
speaker: Narrator

text: And I do eat my morsel by myself, And the orphan hath not eat of it,
speaker: Narrator

text: (But from my youth He grew up with me as [with] a father, And from the belly of my mother I am led.)
speaker: Narrator

text: If I see [any] perishing without clothing, And there is no covering to the needy,
speaker: Narrator

text: If his loins have not blessed me, And from the fleece of my sheep He doth not warm himself,
speaker: Narrator

text: If I have waved at the fatherless my hand, When I see in [him] the gate of my court,
speaker: Narrator

text: My shoulder from its blade let fall, And mine arm from the bone be broken.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a dread unto me [is] calamity [from] God, And because of His excellency I am not able.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I have made gold my confidence, And to the pure gold have said, `My trust,'
speaker: Narrator

text: If I rejoice because great [is] my wealth, And because abundance hath my hand found,
speaker: Narrator

text: If I see the light when it shineth, And the precious moon walking,
speaker: Narrator

text: And my heart is enticed in secret, And my hand doth kiss my mouth,
speaker: Narrator

text: It also [is] a judicial iniquity, For I had lied to God above.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I rejoice at the ruin of my hater, And stirred up myself when evil found him,
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, I have not suffered my mouth to sin, To ask with an oath his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: If not -- say ye, O men of my tent, `O that we had of his flesh, we are not satisfied.'
speaker: Narrator

text: In the street doth not lodge a stranger, My doors to the traveller I open.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I have covered as Adam my transgressions, To hide in my bosom mine iniquity,
speaker: Narrator

text: Because I fear a great multitude, And the contempt of families doth affright me, Then I am silent, I go not out of the opening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who giveth to me a hearing? lo, my mark. The Mighty One doth answer me, And a bill hath mine adversary written.
speaker: Narrator

text: If not -- on my shoulder I take it up, I bind it a crown on myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of my steps I tell Him, As a leader I approach Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If against me my land doth cry out, And together its furrows weep,
speaker: Narrator

text: If its strength I consumed without money, And the life of its possessors, I have caused to breathe out,
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead of wheat let a thorn go forth, And instead of barley a useless weed! The words of Job are finished.
speaker: Narrator

text: And these three men cease from answering Job, for he [is] righteous in his own eyes,
speaker: Narrator

text: and burn doth the anger of Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram; against Job hath his anger burned, because of his justifying himself more than God;
speaker: Narrator

text: and against his three friends hath his anger burned, because that they have not found an answer, and condemn Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Elihu hath waited earnestly beside Job with words, for they are older than he in days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Elihu seeth that there is no answer in the mouth of the three men, and his anger burneth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite answereth and saith: -- Young I [am] in days, and ye [are] age Therefore I have feared, And am afraid of shewing you my opinion.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said: Days do speak, And multitude of years teach wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely a spirit is in man, And the breath of the Mighty One Doth cause them to understand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The multitude are not wise, Nor do the aged understand judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I have said: Hearken to me, I do shew my opinion -- even I.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, I have waited for your words, I give ear unto your reasons, Till ye search out sayings.
speaker: Narrator

text: And unto you I attend, And lo, there is no reasoner for Job, [Or] answerer of his sayings among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lest ye say, We have found wisdom, God doth thrust him away, not man.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he hath not set in array words for me, And with your sayings I do not answer him.
speaker: Narrator

text: (They have broken down, They have not answered again, They removed from themselves words.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I have waited, but they do not speak, For they have stood still, They have not answered any more.)
speaker: Narrator

text: I answer, even I -- my share, I shew my opinion -- even I.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I have been full of words, Distressed me hath the spirit of my breast,
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, my breast [is] as wine not opened, Like new bottles it is broken up.
speaker: Narrator

text: I speak, and there is refreshment to me, I open my lips and answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me not, I pray you, accept the face of any, Nor unto man give flattering titles,
speaker: Narrator

text: For I have not known to give flattering titles, In a little doth my Maker take me away.
speaker: Narrator

text: And yet, I pray thee, O Job, Hear my speech and [to] all my words give ear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, I pray thee, I have opened my mouth, My tongue hath spoken in the palate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of the uprightness of my heart [are] my sayings, And knowledge have my lips clearly spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit of God hath made me, And the breath of the Mighty doth quicken me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If thou art able -- answer me, Set in array before me -- station thyself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, I [am], according to thy word, for God, From the clay I -- I also, have been formed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, my terror doth not frighten thee, And my burden on thee is not heavy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely -- thou hast said in mine ears, And the sounds of words I hear:
speaker: Narrator

text: `Pure [am] I, without transgression, Innocent [am] I, and I have no iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, occasions against me He doth find, He doth reckon me for an enemy to Him,
speaker: Narrator

text: He doth put in the stocks my feet, He doth watch all my paths.'
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, [in] this thou hast not been righteous, I answer thee, that greater is God than man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore against Him hast thou striven, When [for] all His matters He answereth not?
speaker: Narrator

text: For once doth God speak, and twice, (He doth not behold it.)
speaker: Narrator

text: In a dream -- a vision of night, In the falling of deep sleep on men, In slumberings on a bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then He uncovereth the ear of men, And for their instruction sealeth:
speaker: Narrator

text: To turn aside man [from] doing, And pride from man He concealeth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He keepeth back his soul from corruption, And his life from passing away by a dart.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he hath been reproved With pain on his bed, And the strife of his bones [is] enduring.
speaker: Narrator

text: And his life hath nauseated bread, And his soul desirable food.
speaker: Narrator

text: His flesh is consumed from being seen, And high are his bones, they were not seen!
speaker: Narrator

text: And draw near to the pit doth his soul, And his life to those causing death.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there is by him a messenger, An interpreter -- one of a thousand, To declare for man his uprightness:
speaker: Narrator

text: Then He doth favour him and saith, `Ransom him from going down to the pit, I have found an atonement.'
speaker: Narrator

text: Fresher [is] his flesh than a child's, He returneth to the days of his youth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He maketh supplication unto God, And He accepteth him. And he seeth His face with shouting, And He returneth to man His righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looketh on men, and saith, `I sinned, And uprightness I have perverted, And it hath not been profitable to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hath ransomed my soul From going over into the pit, And my life on the light looketh.'
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, all these doth God work, Twice -- thrice with man,
speaker: Narrator

text: To bring back his soul from the pit, To be enlightened with the light of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: Attend, O Job, hearken to me, Keep silent, and I -- I do speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there are words -- answer me, Speak, for I have a desire to justify thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there are not -- hearken thou to me, Keep silent, and I teach thee wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Elihu answereth and saith:
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear, O wise men, my words, And, O knowing ones, give ear to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the ear doth try words, And the palate tasteth to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judgment let us choose for ourselves, Let us know among ourselves what [is] good.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Job hath said, `I have been righteous, And God hath turned aside my right,
speaker: Narrator

text: Against my right do I lie? Mortal [is] mine arrow -- without transgression.'
speaker: Narrator

text: Who [is] a man like Job? He drinketh scoffing like water,
speaker: Narrator

text: And he hath travelled for company With workers of iniquity, So as to go with men of wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he hath said, `It doth not profit a man, When he delighteth himself with God.'
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, O men of heart, hearken to me; Far be it from God to do wickedness, And [from] the Mighty to do perverseness:
speaker: Narrator

text: For the work of man he repayeth to him, And according to the path of each He doth cause him to find.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, truly, God doth not do wickedly, And the Mighty doth not pervert judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who hath inspected for Himself the earth? And who hath placed all the habitable world?
speaker: Narrator

text: If He doth set on him His heart, His spirit and his breath unto Him He gathereth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Expire doth all flesh together, And man to dust returneth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if [there is] understanding, hear this, Give ear to the voice of my words.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, doth one hating justice govern? Or the Most Just dost thou condemn?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who hath said to a king -- `Worthless,' Unto princes -- `Wicked?'
speaker: Narrator

text: That hath not accepted the person of princes, Nor hath known the rich before the poor, For a work of His hands [are] all of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: [In] a moment they die, and at midnight Shake do people, and they pass away, And they remove the mighty without hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: For His eyes [are] on the ways of each, And all his steps He doth see.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is no darkness nor death-shade, For workers of iniquity to be hidden there;
speaker: Narrator

text: For He doth not suffer man any more, To go unto God in judgment,
speaker: Narrator

text: He breaketh the mighty -- no searching! And He appointeth others in their stead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore He knoweth their works, And He hath overturned by night, And they are bruised.
speaker: Narrator

text: As wicked He hath stricken them, In the place of beholders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because that against right They have turned aside from after Him, And none of His ways have considered wisely,
speaker: Narrator

text: To cause to come in unto Him The cry of the poor, And the cry of the afflicted He heareth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He giveth rest, and who maketh wrong? And hideth the face, and who beholdeth it? And in reference to a nation and to a man, [It is] the same.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the reigning of a profane man, From the snares of a people;
speaker: Narrator

text: For unto God hath any said: `I have taken away, I do not corruptly,
speaker: Narrator

text: Besides [that which] I see, shew Thou me, If iniquity I have done -- I do not add?'
speaker: Narrator

text: By thee doth He recompense, That thou hast refused -- That thou dost choose, and not I? And what thou hast known, speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let men of heart say to me, And a wise man is hearkening to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Job -- not with knowledge doth he speak, And his words [are] not with wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: My Father! let Job be tried -- unto victory, Because of answers for men of iniquity,
speaker: Narrator

text: For he doth add to his sin, Transgression among us he vomiteth, And multiplieth his sayings to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Elihu answereth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: This hast thou reckoned for judgment: Thou hast said -- `My righteousness [is] more than God's?'
speaker: Narrator

text: For thou sayest, `What doth it profit Thee! What do I profit from my sin?'
speaker: Narrator

text: I return thee words, and thy friends with thee,
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold attentively the heavens -- and see, And behold the clouds, They have been higher than thou.
speaker: Narrator

text: If thou hast sinned, what dost thou against Him? And thy transgressions have been multiplied, What dost thou to Him?
speaker: Narrator

text: If thou hast been righteous, What dost thou give to Him? Or what from thy hand doth He receive?
speaker: Narrator

text: For a man like thyself [is] thy wickedness, And for a son of man thy righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of the multitude of oppressions They cause to cry out, They cry because of the arm of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: And none said, `Where [is] God my maker? Giving songs in the night,
speaker: Narrator

text: Teaching us more than the beasts of the earth, Yea, than the fowl of the heavens He maketh us wiser.'
speaker: Narrator

text: There they cry, and He doth not answer, Because of the pride of evil doers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely vanity God doth not hear, And the Mighty doth not behold it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, though thou sayest thou dost not behold Him, Judgment [is] before Him, and stay for Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And, now, because there is not, He hath appointed His anger, And He hath not known in great extremity.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job [with] vanity doth open his mouth, Without knowledge words he multiplieth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Elihu addeth and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Honour me a little, and I shew thee, That yet for God [are] words.
speaker: Narrator

text: I lift up my knowledge from afar, And to my Maker I ascribe righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For, truly, my words [are] not false, The perfect in knowledge [is] with thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, God [is] mighty, and despiseth not, Mighty [in] power [and] heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reviveth not the wicked, And the judgment of the poor appointeth;
speaker: Narrator

text: He withdraweth not from the righteous His eyes, And [from] kings on the throne, And causeth them to sit for ever, and they are high,
speaker: Narrator

text: And if prisoners in fetters They are captured with cords of affliction,
speaker: Narrator

text: Then He declareth to them their work, And their transgressions, Because they have become mighty,
speaker: Narrator

text: And He uncovereth their ear for instruction, And saith that they turn back from iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they do hear and serve, They complete their days in good, And their years in pleasantness.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if they do not hearken, By the dart they pass away, And expire without knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the profane in heart set the face, They cry not when He hath bound them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their soul dieth in youth, And their life among the defiled.
speaker: Narrator

text: He draweth out the afflicted in his affliction, And uncovereth in oppression their ear.
speaker: Narrator

text: And also He moved thee from a strait place, [To] a broad place -- no straitness under it, And the sitting beyond of thy table Hath been full of fatness.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the judgment of the wicked thou hast fulfilled, Judgment and justice are upheld -- because of fury,
speaker: Narrator

text: Lest He move thee with a stroke, And the abundance of an atonement turn thee not aside.
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth He value thy riches? He hath gold, and all the forces of power.
speaker: Narrator

text: Desire not the night, For the going up of peoples in their stead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take heed -- do not turn unto iniquity, For on this thou hast fixed Rather than [on] affliction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, God doth sit on high by His power, Who [is] like Him -- a teacher?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who hath appointed unto Him his way? And who said, `Thou hast done iniquity?'
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that thou magnify His work That men have beheld.
speaker: Narrator

text: All men have looked on it, Man looketh attentively from afar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, God [is] high, And we know not the number of His years, Yea, there [is] no searching.
speaker: Narrator

text: When He doth diminish droppings of the waters, They refine rain according to its vapour,
speaker: Narrator

text: Which clouds do drop, They distil on man abundantly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, doth [any] understand The spreadings out of a cloud? The noises of His tabernacle?
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, He hath spread over it His light, And the roots of the sea He hath covered,
speaker: Narrator

text: For by them He doth judge peoples, He giveth food in abundance.
speaker: Narrator

text: By two palms He hath covered the light, And layeth a charge over it in meeting,
speaker: Narrator

text: He sheweth by it [to] his friend substance, Anger against perversity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, at this my heart trembleth, And it moveth from its place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hearken diligently to the trembling of His voice, Yea, the sound from His mouth goeth forth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Under the whole heavens He directeth it, And its light [is] over the skirts of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: After it roar doth a voice -- He thundereth with the voice of His excellency, And He doth not hold them back, When His voice is heard.
speaker: Narrator

text: God thundereth with His voice wonderfully, Doing great things and we know not.
speaker: Narrator

text: For to snow He saith, `Be [on] the earth.' And the small rain and great rain of His power.
speaker: Narrator

text: Into the hand of every man he sealeth, For the knowledge by all men of His work.
speaker: Narrator

text: And enter doth the beast into covert, And in its habitations it doth continue.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the inner chamber cometh a hurricane, And from scatterings winds -- cold,
speaker: Narrator

text: From the breath of God is frost given, And the breadth of waters is straitened,
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, by filling He doth press out a cloud, Scatter a cloud doth His light.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it is turning itself round by His counsels, For their doing all He commandeth them, On the face of the habitable earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whether for a rod, or for His land, Or for kindness -- He doth cause it to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear this, O Job, Stand and consider the wonders of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou know when God doth place them, And caused to shine the light of His cloud?
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou know the balancings of a cloud? The wonders of the Perfect in knowledge?
speaker: Narrator

text: How thy garments [are] warm, In the quieting of the earth from the south?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast made an expanse with Him For the clouds -- strong as a hard mirror!
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us know what we say to Him, We set not in array because of darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it declared to Him that I speak? If a man hath spoken, surely he is swallowed up.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, they have not seen the light, Bright it [is] in the clouds, And the wind hath passed by and cleanseth them.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the golden north it cometh, Beside God [is] fearful honour.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Mighty! we have not found Him out, High in power and judgment, He doth not answer! And abundant in righteousness,
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore do men fear Him, He seeth not any of the wise of heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehovah answereth Job out of the whirlwind, and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Who [is] this -- darkening counsel, By words without knowledge?
speaker: Narrator

text: Gird, I pray thee, as a man, thy loins, And I ask thee, and cause thou Me to know.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where wast thou when I founded earth? Declare, if thou hast known understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who placed its measures -- if thou knowest? Or who hath stretched out upon it a line?
speaker: Narrator

text: On what have its sockets been sunk? Or who hath cast its corner-stone?
speaker: Narrator

text: In the singing together of stars of morning, And all sons of God shout for joy,
speaker: Narrator

text: And He shutteth up with doors the sea, In its coming forth, from the womb it goeth out.
speaker: Narrator

text: In My making a cloud its clothing, And thick darkness its swaddling band,
speaker: Narrator

text: And I measure over it My statute, And place bar and doors,
speaker: Narrator

text: And say, `Hitherto come thou, and add not, And a command is placed On the pride of thy billows.'
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou commanded morning since thy days? Causest thou the dawn to know its place?
speaker: Narrator

text: To take hold on the skirts of the earth, And the wicked are shaken out of it,
speaker: Narrator

text: It turneth itself as clay of a seal And they station themselves as clothed.
speaker: Narrator

text: And withheld from the wicked is their light, And the arm lifted up is broken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou come in to springs of the sea? And in searching the deep Hast thou walked up and down?
speaker: Narrator

text: Revealed to thee were the gates of death? And the gates of death-shade dost thou see?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast understanding, Even unto the broad places of earth! Declare -- if thou hast known it all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where [is] this -- the way light dwelleth? And darkness, where [is] this -- its place?
speaker: Narrator

text: That thou dost take it unto its boundary, And that thou dost understand The paths of its house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast known -- for then thou art born And the number of thy days [are] many!
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou come in unto the treasure of snow? Yea, the treasures of hail dost thou see?
speaker: Narrator

text: That I have kept back for a time of distress, For a day of conflict and battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where [is] this, the way light is apportioned? It scattereth an east wind over the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who hath divided for the flood a conduit? And a way for the lightning of the voices?
speaker: Narrator

text: To cause [it] to rain on a land -- no man, A wilderness -- no man in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: To satisfy a desolate and waste place, And to cause to shoot up The produce of the tender grass?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hath the rain a father? Or who hath begotten the drops of dew?
speaker: Narrator

text: From whose belly came forth the ice? And the hoar-frost of the heavens, Who hath begotten it?
speaker: Narrator

text: As a stone waters are hidden, And the face of the deep is captured.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou bind sweet influences of Kimah? Or the attractions of Kesil dost thou open?
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou bring out Mazzaroth in its season? And Aysh for her sons dost thou comfort?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou known the statutes of heaven? Or dost thou appoint Its dominion in the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou lift up to the cloud thy voice, And abundance of water doth cover thee?
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou send out lightnings, and they go And say unto thee, `Behold us?'
speaker: Narrator

text: Who hath put in the inward parts wisdom? Or who hath given To the covered part understanding?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who doth number the clouds by wisdom? And the bottles of the heavens, Who doth cause to lie down,
speaker: Narrator

text: In the hardening of dust into hardness, And clods cleave together?
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou hunt for a lion prey? And the desire of young lions fulfil?
speaker: Narrator

text: When they bow down in dens -- Abide in a thicket for a covert?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who doth prepare for a raven his provision, When his young ones cry unto God? They wander without food.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou known the time of The bearing of the wild goats of the rock? The bringing forth of hinds thou dost mark!
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou dost number the months they fulfil? And thou hast known the time of their bringing forth!
speaker: Narrator

text: They bow down, Their young ones they bring forth safely, Their pangs they cast forth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Safe are their young ones, They grow up in the field, they have gone out, And have not returned to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who hath sent forth the wild ass free? Yea, the bands of the wild ass who opened?
speaker: Narrator

text: Whose house I have made the wilderness, And his dwellings the barren land,
speaker: Narrator

text: He doth laugh at the multitude of a city, The cries of an exactor he heareth not.
speaker: Narrator

text: The range of mountains [is] his pasture, And after every green thing he seeketh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is a Reem willing to serve thee? Doth he lodge by thy crib?
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou bind a Reem in a furrow [with] his thick band? Doth he harrow valleys after thee?
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou trust in him because great [is] his power? And dost thou leave unto him thy labour?
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou trust in him That he doth bring back thy seed? And [to] thy threshing-floor doth gather [it]?
speaker: Narrator

text: The wing of the rattling ones exulteth, Whether the pinion of the ostrich or hawk.
speaker: Narrator

text: For she leaveth on the earth her eggs, And on the dust she doth warm them,
speaker: Narrator

text: And she forgetteth that a foot may press it, And a beast of the field tread it down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her young ones it hath hardened without her, In vain [is] her labour without fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God hath caused her to forget wisdom, And He hath not given a portion To her in understanding:
speaker: Narrator

text: At the time on high she lifteth herself up, She laugheth at the horse and at his rider.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou give to the horse might? Dost thou clothe his neck [with] a mane?
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou cause him to rush as a locust? The majesty of his snorting [is] terrible.
speaker: Narrator

text: They dig in a valley, and he rejoiceth in power, He goeth forth to meet the armour.
speaker: Narrator

text: He laugheth at fear, and is not affrighted, And he turneth not back from the face of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Against him rattle doth quiver, The flame of a spear, and a halbert.
speaker: Narrator

text: With trembling and rage he swalloweth the ground, And remaineth not stedfast Because of the sound of a trumpet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among the trumpets he saith, Aha, And from afar he doth smell battle, Roaring of princes and shouting.
speaker: Narrator

text: By thine understanding flieth a hawk? Spreadeth he his wings to the south?
speaker: Narrator

text: At thy command goeth an eagle up high? Or lifteth he up his nest?
speaker: Narrator

text: A rock he doth inhabit, Yea, he lodgeth on the tooth of a rock, and fortress.
speaker: Narrator

text: From thence he hath sought food, To a far off place his eyes look attentively,
speaker: Narrator

text: And his brood gulph up blood, And where the pierced [are] -- there [is] he!
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehovah doth answer Job, and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Is the striver with the Mighty instructed? The reprover of God, let him answer it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job answereth Jehovah, and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, I have been vile, What do I return to Thee? My hand I have placed on my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once I have spoken, and I answer not, And twice, and I add not.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehovah answereth Job out of the whirlwind, and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Gird, I pray thee, as a man, thy loins, I ask thee, and cause thou Me to know.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou also make void My judgment? Dost thou condemn Me, That thou mayest be righteous?
speaker: Narrator

text: And an arm like God hast thou? And with a voice like Him dost thou thunder?
speaker: Narrator

text: Put on, I pray thee, excellency and loftiness, Yea, honour and beauty put on.
speaker: Narrator

text: Scatter abroad the wrath of thine anger, And see every proud one, and make him low.
speaker: Narrator

text: See every proud one -- humble him, And tread down the wicked in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hide them in the dust together, Their faces bind in secret.
speaker: Narrator

text: And even I -- I do praise thee, For thy right hand giveth salvation to thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, I pray thee, Behemoth, that I made with thee: Grass as an ox he eateth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, I pray thee, his power [is] in his loins, And his strength in the muscles of his belly.
speaker: Narrator

text: He doth bend his tail as a cedar, The sinews of his thighs are wrapped together,
speaker: Narrator

text: His bones [are] tubes of brass, His bones [are] as a bar of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: He [is] a beginning of the ways of God, His Maker bringeth nigh his sword;
speaker: Narrator

text: For food do mountains bear for him, And all the beasts of the field play there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Under shades he lieth down, In a secret place of reed and mire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cover him do shades, [with] their shadow, Cover him do willows of the brook.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, a flood oppresseth -- he doth not haste, He is confident though Jordan Doth come forth unto his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before his eyes doth [one] take him, With snares doth [one] pierce the nose?
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou draw leviathan with an angle? And with a rope thou lettest down -- his tongue?
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou put a reed in his nose? And with a thorn pierce his jaw?
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth he multiply unto thee supplications? Doth he speak unto thee tender things?
speaker: Narrator

text: Doth he make a covenant with thee? Dost thou take him for a servant age-during?
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou play with him as a bird? And dost thou bind him for thy damsels?
speaker: Narrator

text: (Feast upon him do companions, They divide him among the merchants!)
speaker: Narrator

text: Dost thou fill with barbed irons his skin? And with fish-spears his head?
speaker: Narrator

text: Place on him thy hand, Remember the battle -- do not add!
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, the hope of him is found a liar, Also at his appearance is not one cast down?
speaker: Narrator

text: None so fierce that he doth awake him, And who [is] he before Me stationeth himself?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who hath brought before Me and I repay? Under the whole heavens it [is] mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: I do not keep silent concerning his parts, And the matter of might, And the grace of his arrangement.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who hath uncovered the face of his clothing? Within his double bridle who doth enter?
speaker: Narrator

text: The doors of his face who hath opened? Round about his teeth [are] terrible.
speaker: Narrator

text: A pride -- strong ones of shields, Shut up -- a close seal.
speaker: Narrator

text: One unto another they draw nigh, And air doth not enter between them.
speaker: Narrator

text: One unto another they adhere, They stick together and are not separated.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sneezings cause light to shine, And his eyes [are] as the eyelids of the dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of his mouth do flames go, sparks of fire escape.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of his nostrils goeth forth smoke, As a blown pot and reeds.
speaker: Narrator

text: His breath setteth coals on fire, And a flame from his mouth goeth forth.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his neck lodge doth strength, And before him doth grief exult.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flakes of his flesh have adhered -- Firm upon him -- it is not moved.
speaker: Narrator

text: His heart [is] firm as a stone, Yea, firm as the lower piece.
speaker: Narrator

text: From his rising are the mighty afraid, From breakings they keep themselves free.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sword of his overtaker standeth not, Spear -- dart -- and lance.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reckoneth iron as straw, brass as rotten wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of the bow doth not cause him to flee, Turned by him into stubble are stones of the sling.
speaker: Narrator

text: As stubble have darts been reckoned, And he laugheth at the shaking of a javelin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Under him [are] sharp points of clay, He spreadeth gold on the mire.
speaker: Narrator

text: He causeth to boil as a pot the deep, The sea he maketh as a pot of ointment.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him he causeth a path to shine, One thinketh the deep to be hoary.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is not on the earth his like, That is made without terror.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every high thing he doth see, He [is] king over all sons of pride.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job answereth Jehovah and saith: --
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast known that [for] all things Thou art able, And not withheld from Thee is [any] device:
speaker: Narrator

text: `Who [is] this, hiding counsel without knowledge?' Therefore, I have declared, and understand not, Too wonderful for me, and I know not.
speaker: Narrator

text: `Hear, I pray thee, and I -- I do speak, I ask thee, and cause thou me to know.'
speaker: Narrator

text: By the hearing of the ear I heard Thee, And now mine eye hath seen Thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore do I loathe [it], And I have repented on dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it cometh to pass after Jehovah's speaking these words unto Job, that Jehovah saith unto Eliphaz the Temanite, `Burned hath Mine anger against thee, and against thy two friends, because ye have not spoken concerning Me rightly, like My servant Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, take to you seven bullocks and seven rams, and go ye unto My servant Job, and ye have caused a burnt-offering to ascend for you; and Job My servant doth pray for you, for surely his face I accept, so as not to do with you folly, because ye have not spoken concerning Me rightly, like My servant Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they go -- Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, Zophar the Naamathite -- and do as Jehovah hath spoken unto them; and Jehovah doth accept the face of Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehovah hath turned [to] the captivity of Job in his praying for his friends, and Jehovah doth add [to] all that Job hath -- to double.
speaker: Narrator

text: And come unto him do all his brethren, and all his sisters, and all his former acquaintances, and they eat bread with him in his house, and bemoan him, and comfort him concerning all the evil that Jehovah had brought upon him, and they gave to him each one kesitah, and each one ring of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehovah hath blessed the latter end of Job more than his beginning, and he hath fourteen thousand of a flock, and six thousand camels, and a thousand pairs of oxen, and a thousand she-asses.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he hath seven sons and three daughters;
speaker: Narrator

text: and he calleth the name of the one Jemima, and the name of the second Kezia, and the name of the third Keren-Happuch.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there have not been found women fair as the daughters of Job in all the land, and their father doth give to them an inheritance in the midst of their brethren.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job liveth after this a hundred and forty years, and seeth his sons, and his sons' sons, four generations;
speaker: Narrator

text: and Job dieth, aged and satisfied [with] days.
speaker: Narrator
